en_first_half: “I was only fifteen when Grandpa died. We were all at the reading of the will, but you can imagine in a situation like that, especially for kids, a lot of the details sort of go over your head. The reading took hours. I understood,
en_second_half: basically, that he was leaving us each a very large sum of money. I understood that it was contingent on us being married. At the time, it didn’t seem so weird that he would want that. Kids sort of take those adult directives as law.”
en_results_raw: As the will was being read, I tried to focus on the legal terms and the distribution of assets, but my mind kept wandering to the memories of Grandpa. He had always been a source of strength and wisdom, and I couldn’t help but wonder how life would be without him. The room was filled with relatives, some I barely knew, and the atmosphere was tense. Despite the gravity of the moment, I found myself glancing at my cousins, who were equally distracted. After the reading, we all went our separate ways, each of us processing the news in our own way. The house felt different, quieter, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that something had changed irrevocably. In the days that followed, I realized that the will had not only changed our financial situation but also our family dynamics, and I was left to grapple with the new reality.
